report_title: Paperboard Drinking Cup Manufacturing Industry Report
executive_summary: The Paperboard Drinking Cup Manufacturing industry produces paper and paperboard cups that hold liquid. Industry goods are primarily sold to wholesalers and retailers, and are typically purchased by restaurants and drinking places and household consumers. The industry has experienced

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Paperboard Drinking Cup Manufacturing industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Paperboard Drinking Cup Manufacturing industry produces paper and paperboard cups that hold liquid. Industry goods are primarily sold to wholesalers and retailers, and typically end up in the hands of restaurants and drinking places and household consumers. Demand for paperboard cups generally follows broader economic trends, such as consumer spending and industrial production. When the economy is expanding, manufacturing output of industry products grows alongside consumer demand for hot and cold beverages served in paper cups.

Over the five years to 2022, industry operators have contended with significant economic challenges that were exacerbated by the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic in 2020. The pandemic hampered demand from food services and drinking places and precipitated consumer spending falling 3.8% in 2020 alone. Moreover, by 2020, industry exports had declined for the fifth consecutive year. An economic recovery in 2021 and 2022 fueled a rise in consumer spending, total trade and corporate profit, all of which have

Despite generally positive economic conditions during most of the period, industry operators were struck hard by the coronavirus pandemic in 2020. Demand from food services and drinking places, one of the industry's largest end markets and a significant source of demand, fell 37.8% in 2020 alone. As global economies were affected, the total value of trade fell 10.9% that year as well. Although industry exports began declining prior to the pandemic, it precipitated exports to decline 25.8% in 2020. Ultimately, industry revenue fell 20.4% in 2020.

During the period, the industry has contended with increased environmental consciousness and a heightened awareness surrounding the environmental impacts of paperboard cup production. According to a study by the Environmental Defense Fund and Starbucks, the production of one 16.0-ounce paper cup releases 0.25 pounds of CO2 emissions, with every four cups emitting one pound of CO2. Despite the common belief that paper and paperboard cups are good for the environment, many of these cups are not recyclable due to a polyethylene coating that prevents the paper from absorbing liquid.

Recent attempts to properly recycle paper and paperboard cups by separating the paper from the plastic have proven possible, but on a small scale. In 2018, Starbucks Corporation (Starbucks) successfully recycled 25.0 million cups in a Wisconsin paper mill, and used the recycled fiber to produce new cups. Since then, more and more paper recycling mills have begun to accept paper cups. According to the American Forest and Paper Association,

Amid economic declines and environmental threats, industry participation has remained stagnant, remaining at 25 enterprises over the five years to 2022. While there have been no new entrants to the industry, existing operators have sought to cut costs to stay afloat. Consequently, industry wages have declined significantly, falling an annualized 5.6% to $241.8 million over the five years to 2022. Despite attempts to cut costs, industry profit has fallen as well, curbed by rising input prices.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Paperboard Drinking Cup Manufacturing industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Paperboard Drinking Cup Manufacturing industry is anticipated return to growth over the five years to 2027 as key downstream markets recover from economic declines. Demand from food services and drinking places is anticipated to rise after plummeting amid the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic in 2020. Consumer spending and corporate profit are expected to increase, facilitating demand for paper and paperboard cups. Moreover, the trade-weighted index (TWI), which measures the value of the US dollar compared with key trading partners' currency, is anticipated to fall, making domestic goods relatively less expensive and fueling industry exports.

Demand trends for paperboard drinking cups generally follow broader economic conditions, since downstream markets primarily include the Accommodation and Food Services sector (IBISWorld report 72) and household consumers. Pent-up demand following the coronavirus pandemic is expected to lead to more social gatherings, travel and dining out, all of which will contribute to heightened demand for industry products. Over the five years to 2022, consumer spending is expected to increase an annualized 1.7%. Meanwhile, demand from food services and drinking places is

Revenue growth over the next five years will likely be mitigated by concerns surrounding paper and paperboard cups' negative effects on the environment. According to Earth911, an estimated 60.0 billion paper cups end up in landfills in the United States every year, while less than 1.0% of paper cups from coffee chains are recycled. Efforts to recycle paper cups that contain a polyethylene coating are anticipated to continue growing over the next five years, with more paper recycling mills across the United States expected to accept paper cups.

Environmental concerns are anticipated to spread across the globe over the next five years, affecting foreign demand for paperboard cups, and thus, exports. Nevertheless, an anticipated devaluation of the US dollar and global economic recoveries following the coronavirus pandemic are anticipated to boost industry exports. Over the five years to 2027, the value of exports is expected to increase an annualized 2.7% to $308.2 million, generating 14.9% of industry revenue in 2027. Despite a depreciating dollar, imports are expected to rise as well, growing an annualized 1.2% to $339.7 million over the five years.

industry_definition: This industry includes companies that convert paperboard into drinking cups and portion serving cups. These are primarily sold to wholesalers and retailers for final sale to or use by restaurants and consumers.
key_trends: Import penetration has greatly affected industry revenue
As both consumers and corporations have increased efforts to fight climate change, industry revenue has suffered
Existing operators have sought to cut costs to stay afloat

tier_1_suppliers: Wood Pulp Mills in the US
Industrial Machinery & Equipment Wholesaling in the US
Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Restaurant Supply Stores in the US
Restaurant & Hotel Equipment Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_buyers: Fast Food Restaurants in the US
Coffee & Snack Shops in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Downstream demand is dependent upon consumer spending and household income. As consumer spending rises, demand from food services and drinking places increases, supporting industry revenue.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Imports and Value of the Dollar
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The level of imports also effects industry demand. Competition within the industry is determined upon price so as the value of the dollar increases, its purchasing power internationally increases, which in turn, increases import penetration for industry operators.

Changing consumers preferences also has an effect on the industry. As more consumers become more environmentally conscious, they may elect to use reusable cups as opposed to using disposable paperboard cups to reduce waste.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports account for a moderate share of domestic demand in 2022, comprising an estimated 16.7% of demand. While industry revenue has declined, imports have increased, rising at an annualized rate of 7.7% to $320.0 million over the five years to 2022.
Industry exports comprise an estimated 14.4% of revenue in 2022. Unlike imports, exports have fallen during the period, declining an annualized 1.9% to $269.6 million over the five years to 2022.

business_locations.location_description: Establishments within the Paperboard Drinking Cup Manufacturing are most highly concentrated in the Southeast region. The Southeast region is expected to account for 26.0% of industry establishments in 2022, in line with the region's share of the population.

The Great Lakes region accounts for the second-most industry establishments, home to 25.4% of industry establishments in 2022. While the percentage of establishments in the Great Lakes region is considerably higher than its share of the population, nearly one-quarter of paperboard mills are located in the Great Lakes.
The West region is expected to account for 13.3% of industry establishments in 2022. Operators within this region are concentrated in California, which accounts for 10.7% of locations in 2022.
Establishments in the Mid-Atlantic region are expected to account for 10.0% of industry establishments in 2022.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The industry must abide by broad regulations that affect the entire manufacturing sector. These regulations include the Clean Water Act (CWA), Solid Waste Disposal Act (SWDA), Clean Air Act (CAA), the Cluster Rule and noise pollution control. In adherence to the CWA and SWDA, industry operators are responsible for properly disposing of water and solid waste. Under the CAA, the industry must limit their air pollutants, such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxides, sulfur oxides and other particulate matter to protect the health and wellbeing of the public. The Cluster Rule was established to reduce the amount of both air and water pollutants produced by manufacturers. Finally, to control noise pollution, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) monitors different types of industrial machinery considered noise pollutants through their noise emission standard.

New laws that either tax or ban the usage of industry products may threaten the industry. For example, in Berkeley, CA, a new law was passed that charges consumers a small fee for using disposable coffee cups. These regulations may become more prevalent and widespread over the outlook period, hurting demand for industry products.

The coronavirus pandemic affected the production process of the manufacturing sector in the United States. Industry operators had to comply with social distancing guidelines to stop the spread of the virus. To comply with these guidelines many operators had to reduce of the number of workers that could produce their products at the same time, inhibiting their output. Workers also had to comply with mask mandates and increased cleaning procedures.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Life Cycle Stage: mature, Revenue Volatility Level: high, Industry Assistance Level: low - steady

The main barrier to entry for industry operators is start-up costs on machinery to produce industry products. Depending on economic conditions, the purchase of machinery can be more or less expensive depending upon interest rates as machinery is typically purchased on credit. Another barrier to entry is finding suitable employees. According to the National Association of Manufacturers, there are many job openings in the manufacturing industry and a major business challenge for manufacturers is finding skilled workers. Finally, competing for long term contracts from downstream markets is another barrier to entry for the industry. Operators entering the industry must achieve economies of scale to compete with existing operators to establish long term contracts as contracts are based upon price.

basis_points.basis_description: Competition within the Paperboard Drinking Cup manufacturing industry is moderate. Most internal competition is based upon price, since it is difficult to differentiate industry products. Long-term contracts are very important to industry operators, which is why operators must keep production costs low to compete.

There are several sources of external competition for industry operators. Firstly, industry operators must compete with imports from low-cost foreign producers. In addition, a source of external competition for cold cups is plastic disposable cups. Since plastic disposable cups cannot be used for hot cups, as the plastic will melt into the cup due to the hot liquid, this is not a source of competition for this product segment. However, reusable cups are a source of competition for hot cups and this trend is expected to increase over the outlook period as consumers continually become more environmentally conscious.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The Paperboard Drinking Cup Manufacturing industry has a low level of market share concentration. Market share concentration has increased over the five years to 2022 as larger operators have improved operational efficiencies and are able to compete with smaller operators on the basis of the price they sell products for. Another reason that market share concentration has increased during the current period is the number of operators within the industry has remained stagnant.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, is anticipated to comprise 4.5% of industry revenue in 2022, down from 5.7% in 2017. Profit levels have yet to fully recover from declines associated with the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic in 2020, which led to a significant drop in the average operator's Moreover, purchase costs have increased over the five years to 2022, cutting into profit. Notably, the price of paper, the industry's primary input, has increased an annualized 4.8% over the five years to 2022. Profit is anticipated to increase marginally over the next five years as demand for industry products increases.

Wages account for an estimated 12.9% of industry revenue in 2022. Wage costs have fallen alongside revenue during the period, as declining demand has forced operators to cut costs. However, wages' share of revenue has increased marginally, from 12.7% in 2017. Moving forward, labor is expected to remain a steady share of revenue.

Purchases are the industry's most significant cost component, accounting for an estimated 64.1% of revenue in 2022. Purchase costs have increased during the period as input costs, such as the price of paper, have grown. The primary materials used in the production of industry goods are paper and paperboard. Strong demand for these commodities, mainly from developing countries, increases the cost of these inputs, causing purchase costs to rise. Simultaneously, a trend toward using expensive recycled materials continues to grow, leading to higher purchase expenses for operators.

Depreciation expenses are estimated to account for 2.4% of revenue in 2022. Depreciation costs fluctuate among operators depending on size and the number of assets involved. Depreciable assets include storage equipment, manufacturing machinery, computer inventory systems and other manufacturing hardware.
Marketing costs are low for this industry, which is typical for a manufacturing industry. In 2022, marketing costs are expected to account for 0.0% of revenue.

Rent costs are relatively low for this industry as many large operators own plants and warehouses. However, smaller operators tend to rent spaces. Consequently, rent costs are estimated to account for 1.1% of revenue in 2022.

Utility costs include electricity, water, gas, fuels and other similar commodities. Manufacturers typically require high and steady levels of energy for the heavy machinery. Utilities costs accounts for 1.3% of industry revenue in 2022.
Other costs are anticipated to account for 13.6% of revenue in 2022. This segment includes overhead expenses, logistics, administrative costs and research and development.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: IBISWorld estimates that for every $1.00 spent on wages, operators will allocate $0.19 in capital investment in 2022. The industry's level of capital intensity has remained relatively stable over the five years to 2022.

During the period, operators have experienced diminishing returns from capital investment as demand for industry products has fallen. This has discouraged new operators from entering the industry and precipitated existing operators to cut both wage and capital costs.
Nonetheless, advancements in new technology systems and increased computerization have resulted in improved labor productivity over the past five years.
Capital intensity is expected to remain stable moving forward and investment in labor and capital grow simultaneously.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry's performance typically falls in line with that of the broader US economy and the Accommodation and Food Services sector (IBISWorld report 72). Restaurants and coffee shops use paper and paperboard cups to serve takeaway beverages in. End consumers typically purchase industry goods to serve beverages at social gatherings.
The COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic in 2020 precipitated the industry's most significant decline of the period, with revenue falling 20.4% that year alone.
Revenue has increased as much as 11.5% in 2021. Revenue volatility is anticipated to fall over the five years to 2027.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: In the Paperboard Drinking Cup Manufacturing industry, the materials used to make paperboard cups are mostly paperboard, however most products are given a polyethylene coating to make cups liquid proof. This coating can make it difficult for paperboard cups to be recycled and there are only a few recycling facilities that are capable of fully recycling these cups. Major player Huhtamaki Group (Huhtamaki) has developed a new cup with its "EarthCoating" that enables its cups to be recycled in mainstream recycling facilities. Another new product that Huhtamaki offers is its compostable hot cups which according to the company are made from paperboard from sustainably managed forests. As regulations on single use cups are expected to increase, the need for paperboard cups to become easily recyclable or compostable could affect industry operators.

Most technological change within the Paperboard Cup Manufacturing industry has been through the improvement of the industry's production process. The actual production of industry products has not drastically changed in recent years, but the computerization of the production process

FAQs.question: Has your company benefited from declining levels of imports during the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Imported products are manufactured with lower-cost inputs, keeping prices of foreign products lower than domestically produced goods and posing a threat to industry operators. If your company remains threatened by imports, try marketing the environmental or quality benefits of your product to consumers, as these are qualities that lower cost manufacturers cannot easily copy.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: While producing specialized paper cups can increase operating costs, there is likely to be less competition in specialized markets. Ensure your company has a comparative advantage in these specialized markets so you do not waste resources that could be better spent on increasing non-specialized production.

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions of the country?
FAQs.answer: Automation in the Manufacturing Sector has contributed to declining wages throughout the country. Still, moving your company to match the labor pool your company would benefit from may be worth the short-term cost increase of moving.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities or been approached by larger companies looking for growth opportunities?
FAQs.answer: Large manufacturers in this industry have looked for small companies to acquire to create economies of scale and reduce operating costs. An increase in the cost of borrowing is anticipated in the next several months, so companies may want to consider borrowing early for any potential acquisitions.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Machinery and equipment used by industry operators have become increasingly computerized, improving the speed of operations and reducing human error. Computerized paper processing machines are increasingly being used by the smallest operators.

FAQs.question: What steps have you taken to protect your company's information from cyber attacks?
FAQs.answer: Large companies are often targeted by hackers because many manufacturers have a significant amount of customer data. As goods shipping underpins the entire United States economy, your company may be at a greater risk than you think.

FAQs.question: Has your company embraced growing demand for environmentally-friendly products?
FAQs.answer: Investing in machinery and technology to produce environmentally friendly products can be costly for operators, but can also allow companies to tap into new markets. Increasing regulations on eco-conscious packaging may be made into state or national law within the next several years.

FAQs.question: How has your company adjusted operations to comply with COVID-19 social distancing regulations?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators must ensure that workers are able to stay healthy to avoid shutdowns, which can result in supply chain disruptions. Increasing investment in automation may reduce the risk of later labor challenges, but be aware that any furloughed workers may be irritated if their positions are cancelled.

FAQs.question: Has your company invested in machinery and equipment that can increase automation?
FAQs.answer: Since industry operations are highly dependent on machinery and equipment to produce products, new equipment is typically a major investment for industry operators. As the cost of borrowing is anticipated to increase, investing now is likely to cost less overall than borrowing in several months.

FAQs.question: Have COVID-19 regulations impacted your company's profit margins?
FAQs.answer: Implementing social distancing measures and providing personal protective equipment have increased operating costs for most manufacturers.

FAQs.question: Do you have contacts with key distributors and end users? Are you located close to any major online retailers or distributors?
FAQs.answer: Retailers are the primary market for paperboard drinking cups. Having contacts within key markets.

FAQs.question: Do you have contacts with key suppliers? Are you located near major suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Paper is the primary input for industry operators. Long term contracts with suppliers can shield operators from volatility in input prices. Guaranteed supply of key inputs.

FAQs.question: How much do you invest in research and development? Is specialization one of your company's selling points?
FAQs.answer: Research and development maximizes the possibility of developing higher quality products with faster production schedules. Developing more biodegradable products and reducing the environmental impact of manufacturing may enable marketing to a wider range of clients. Undertaking technical research and development.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuations in the trade-weighted index affect international demand for your products? Has your company experienced export disruption amid the coronavirus pandemic?
FAQs.answer: An increase in the trade-weighted index makes industry products relatively more expensive for consumers.

FAQs.question: Does your company monitor the price of paper? When the price of paper is high, how is your profitability affected?
FAQs.answer: Paper is the industry's primary input. Operators can typically pass on a rise in the price of paper to consumers.

FAQs.question: Do you track consumer spending? How did you mitigate the threat of declining consumer spending amid the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Consumer spending is a primary driver of industry performance.
